address: SAVE SIGHT FOUNDATION NO 26 ANNAMALAI LAYOUT OPP TO ROYAL THEATRE NEAR BUS STANDERODE 638011
title: Save Sight Foundation
detailsOfAchievement: Arasan Eye hospital was established in the year 1997 with the aim of providing affordable eye care for all. In the year 2000 we established our charitable wing Save Sight Foundation . Through this unit we conduct free eye camps . So far we have done 5934 free eye camps. We have screened 459231 patients and have done 101408 free surgeries. Through the trust we have also established an Eye bank in 2001. Arasan Eye bank has collected 11545 eyes and 635 Keratoplasties so far. In collaboration with Rotary International Dr.VPS has conducted several mega eye camps in Ghana, West Africa. The Governments of Mali and Zimbabwe have MOU with Arasan for training their doctors. On invitation from the Chattisgarh Government the trust conducted Mega eye camps in the tribal belt of Dhandewada District in 2009. We also conduct Cataract surgery training program in both SICS and Phaco from 2003 onwards. So far 420 Indian doctors and 163 International doctors have benefitted from this course. As part of VISION 2020, The Right to Sight , major international efforts will be made in areas such as information and resource mobilization, joint planning and building national capacity through human resource development and transfer of appropriate technologies to developing countries. The trust is deeply involved in this initiative. Arasan Eye Hospital is accredited by National Board of Examinations to conduct their DNB course from 2007. So far six DNB candidates have passed out. Every year 4 students are enrolled in the course. Apart from this 2 candidates are taken as fellows in General ophthalmology. The students are taught in the clinical discipline by trained faculty . At present we have eleven DNB residents in our institution. In Collaboration with Bharathiyar University the trust offers Advanced Diploma Course in Ophthalmic Nursing . Under this scheme 25 girls from rural pockets of Tamilnadu are admitted . They are given free education , boarding and Lodging. So far 65 girls have benefitted. Diabetic Eye screening camps , School screening camps and Glaucoma awareness camps are also conducted by the trust. In appreciation of our work the Tamilnadu Ophthalmic Association awarded the prestigious Dr.G. Venkatasamy Community Ophthalmology Oration award in 2010. In 2016 the Association of Community Ophthalmologist of India (ACOIN)gave the Mrs. Sushila Biswal Memorial ACOIN Award , 2015 at Trichy.

RECURRING GRANT FOR CLINICAL SERVICES, MENTAL HEALTH AWARENESS PROGRAM AND REHABILITATION SERVICES

This is a 5 year study on assessing the role of the family and associated variables that contribute to the outcome of schizophrenia in first episode cases in India and Canada. Based on the study findings suitable interventions can be devised that would contribute to better outcomes for patients.

Genome wide association studies in schizophrenia have identified several risk loci in western populations. This study will replicate the SNPs identified in the western populations in Indian population to see if they are common. The following genes will be studied: MIR137 (rs1625579), ZFN804A9 (rs1344706), CACNA1C (rs476905), TCF4 (rs9960967), NRGN (rs12807809), ANK3 (rs10994359), MHC NOTCH4 (rs3131296) and TP53 (rs1042522).

sourceOfFunds.purpose: The TANSACS - FSW - TI is exclusively for prevent the peoples from the transmission of HIV - AIDS. This project is undergoing in Cuddalore district Since 2012. Also done the massive differences in comparing with previous years towards the prevention progress.

Palliative care is an approach that improves the quality of life of patients and their families facing the problem associated with life-threatening illness, through the prevention and relief of suffering by means of early identification and impeccable assessment and treatment of pain and other problems, physical, psychosocial and spiritual. As per above said we were doing palliative care service and provding support for those who chronically ill and bed ridden.

Demand for more competent nurses to provide palliative care services was the key for the formation of this organization with a specific goal of imparting most up-to-date knowledge and skills to address the patients confronted by a number of diseases, community girls are encouraged to volunteer themselves in taking part in training and given the opportunity to serve in their own community this will ensure development and sustainability from within through local participation and ownership.

title: SERVANTS OF MARY IMMACULATE
detailsOfAchievement: - 65 first generation gypsy children began to think about the possibility of learning instead of going with their parents for making plastic flowers and begging. - All 65 of them began to apply soap in their body while bathing. - They learned to wash their dresses and reuse them instead of throwing away after using them till they tear. - Children learned to sit and participate in classes conduted - Children learned to read and write both English and Tamil alphabet besides learning the numbers.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Servants of Mary Immaculate -SMI organized two units of Residential Special Training Centers (RSTC) in Kariyasandiram village, Shoolagiri block for children of Gypsy Community and the Irular children of Sigarlapalli Gate area. Of the 65 children, some had begging, while the others had child labor or roaming in the sun background. All these first generation learners were motivated and oriented to involve in the learning process. This RSTC considerably reduced begging, child labour

Servants of Mary Immaculate organized (SMI) two units of Residential Special Training Center (RSTC) in Kariyasandiram for Gypsy and Irular children of Shoolagiri block. Unit 1 had 77 children and Unit 2 had 17 children. SMI provided comprehensive care, nourishing food, enabling education, life skill, yoga, exposure, vocational training etc. that helped to induct forty six students in the newly established Primary school at Kariyasandiram itself. 21 students were mainstreamed in regular schools.

Servants of Mary Immaculate succeeded in bringing the Gypsy and Irular children out of their dark reality of insufficient interest in education to learn. SSA helped to organize the Residential School in Berigai. SSA again gifted with a new building and spacious playground at Athimugam in Dec. 2015. Of the eighty five children moved here, 23 were newly enrolled. Holding the children in the Residential School drastically reduced begging, child labor, alcohol drinking, domestic violence etc.

Residential Training Center received the status of Access Residential School at Athimugam. With a big play ground and spacious infrastructure, Servants of Mary Immaculate educated 105 students in 2016-17 with the help of SSA. Of them, 27 were newly enrolled. â€œAre they never enrolled
